title: Week 1 Main Quiz
description: Main quiz for Week 1 covering current week's topics and bonus questions from previous week

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Computer Science?
options: The study of how to build and maintain computer hardware.
The study of computation, algorithms, and information.
The practice of writing software for business applications.
The design and implementation of computer networks.

questions.question: What is a key design philosophy of the Go programming language?
options: Extensive use of inheritance and complex class hierarchies.
Emphasis on simplicity, readability, and efficient concurrency.
Heavy reliance on dynamic typing and metaprogramming.
Prioritization of functional programming paradigms above all else.
questions.topicTitle: Introduction to the Go Programming Language

questions.question: In the context of setting up a development environment, what is VS Code primarily used for?
options: Running Go programs in a virtual machine.
A code editor with extensions for writing and debugging code.
questions.topicTitle: Setting up Your Development Environment (VS Code & Terminal)

questions.question: What is the purpose of the `package main` declaration in a Go program?
options: It signifies that the package is for internal use only.
It indicates that the package defines a library that can be imported by other programs.
It declares an executable program, signifying it's the entry point.
It's used for defining external dependencies.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically considered a sub-discipline of Computer Science?
What is the command typically used in a terminal to navigate to a different directory?
questions.topicTitle: Setting up Your Development Environment (VS Code & Terminal)

questions.question: In the 'Hello, World!' Go program, what is the role of the `fmt` package?
options: To perform input and output operations, like printing to the console.

questions.question: Go's concurrency features are often associated with which of the following concepts?
questions.topicTitle: Introduction to the Go Programming Language

title: Week 2 Main Quiz
description: Main quiz for Week 2 covering current week's topics and bonus questions from previous week

questions.question: Which Go data type is used to represent whole numbers, both positive and negative?
What is the primary purpose of the `:=` operator in Go?
options: To declare a variable of a specific type.
To assign a value to an existing variable.
To declare and initialize a variable with type inference.

questions.question: Which of the following keywords is used to declare a constant in Go?
In Go, what is the result of the expression `10 / 3` when both operands are integers?

Consider the following Go code snippet:

```go
var isComplete bool = true

if isComplete {
    fmt.Println("Done!")
}
```

What will be printed to the console?
What does it mean for a variable to be 'untyped' in the context of Go constants?
options: It cannot be assigned a value.
It does not have a fixed underlying type and can be used in contexts requiring different types.
It must be declared using the `var` keyword.
It is automatically initialized to zero.

questions.question: Which operator is used to check if two boolean expressions are both true in Go?
If you declare a variable using `var myVar float64`, and do not explicitly assign a value, what will its initial value be?
What is the main command used to run a Go program from the terminal?
questions.topicTitle: Setting up Your Development Environment (VS Code & Terminal)

questions.question: In Go, what does the `package main` declaration signify?
options: It indicates that the package is intended for use by other packages.
It is a required declaration for any Go package.
It signifies that the package is an executable program.
It imports a specific set of standard library functions.

title: Week 1 Refresher Quiz
description: Optional refresher quiz for Week 1 - questions change each time

questions.question: Beyond computational theory, what is a significant driving force behind the evolution of Computer Science as a discipline?
options: The pursuit of purely mathematical elegance
The demand for solutions to real-world problems and technological advancement
The historical legacy of early computing pioneers
The development of theoretical algorithms without practical application

questions.question: What design principle is a cornerstone of Go's philosophy, aimed at making code easier to understand and maintain?
options: Extensive use of complex inheritance hierarchies
Prioritizing developer productivity through explicit error handling and clear syntax
Encouraging meta-programming for dynamic code generation
Maximizing abstraction to hide implementation details completely
questions.topicTitle: Introduction to the Go Programming Language

questions.question: When working with Go in VS Code, which of the following is a common and highly recommended extension for enhancing Go development?
options: A Go-specific extension providing linting, debugging, and IntelliSense

questions.question: In the context of a Go program, what is the primary purpose of the `package main` declaration?
options: To define a reusable module for other programs
To indicate that the package is an executable program

questions.question: Which sub-discipline of Computer Science often focuses on algorithms, data structures, and the theoretical limits of computation?
What is a key advantage of Go's built-in support for concurrency?
options: It requires complex external libraries to manage threads
It allows for efficient handling of multiple tasks simultaneously without significant overhead
It is primarily designed for single-threaded applications
It introduces significant performance bottlenecks for parallel execution
questions.topicTitle: Introduction to the Go Programming Language

questions.question: Imagine you've navigated into a directory named 'my_project' using your terminal. To create a new empty file named 'main.go' within this directory, which command would you use?
In a Go program, what is the purpose of the `import` statement?
options: To make functions and variables from other packages available for use
To print output to the console

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common use case for the Go programming language, as discussed in Week 1?
options: Building scalable network services and APIs
Developing client-side web applications with complex UIs
questions.topicTitle: Introduction to the Go Programming Language

questions.question: If you are in a terminal and want to change your current directory to a subdirectory named 'src' that resides within your current location, what command would you execute?

title: Week 2 Dynamic Quiz
description: Personalized quiz targeting your weak areas from Week 2

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct way to declare an integer variable named 'age' and initialize it with the value 30 using short variable declaration in Go?

Consider the following Go code snippet:

```go
var score int
score = 95
```

What is the initial value of `score` before it is assigned 95?

What will be the output of the following Go code?

```go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	result := 10 + 5 * 2
	fmt.Println(result)
}
```
In Go, what does the `:=` operator do?
options: It declares a variable without initializing it.
It declares and initializes a variable with type inference.
It assigns a new value to an existing variable.

questions.question: Evaluate the following Go expression: `7 % 3`

Consider this Go code:

```go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	var count int
	count = 10
	count := 5 // This will cause an error
	fmt.Println(count)
}
```

Why will the line `count := 5` cause an error?
options: You cannot reassign a value to a variable declared with `var`.
You cannot redeclare a variable in the same scope.
The `:=` operator can only be used for initializing new variables.
Integer types cannot be assigned repeatedly.

questions.question: What is the result of the logical expression `(true || false) && !false` in Go?
options: Depends on the order of operations

questions.question: Which of the following Go statements correctly declares a variable named `temperature` using `var` and specifies its type as float64, initializing it to 25.5?

Consider the Go code:

```go
package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
	a := 10
	b := 3
	fmt.Println(a / b)
}
```

What will be the output?
In Go, when you declare a variable using `var name string` without explicit initialization, what is its zero value?

title: Week 3 Main Quiz
description: Main quiz for Week 3 covering current week's topics and bonus questions from previous week

questions.question: Which statement is used to execute a block of code only if a specified condition is true in Go?
In Go, the `switch` statement can have a `default` case. When does the `default` case execute?
options: Always, regardless of the switch expression
If no other `case` matches the switch expression
Only if the switch expression is zero

questions.question: By default, in a Go `switch` statement, does a `case` automatically 'fall through' to the next `case`?
options: No, each `case` must explicitly end with `break`
No, each `case` automatically exits the `switch` block
Only if the `fallthrough` keyword is used

questions.question: Which form of the `for` loop in Go is used to iterate a specific number of times, often with an initialization, condition, and post-statement?
What is the primary function of the `break` statement within a loop in Go?
options: To skip the current iteration and move to the next
To immediately terminate the loop and exit its block
To restart the loop from the beginning
To print the current loop counter

questions.question: Which `switch` statement form in Go is used when you want to execute code without any specific condition, similar to a catch-all?
In Go, what is the result of the expression `5 / 2` if both operands are integers?
Which Go operator is used to check if two values are NOT equal?

title: Week 4 Main Quiz
description: Main quiz for Week 4 covering current week's topics and bonus questions from previous week

questions.question: Which of the following best describes a fixed-size array in Go?
options: A collection of elements that can grow or shrink dynamically.
A data structure with a fixed number of elements that are all of the same type.
A key-value pair collection where keys must be unique.
A sequence of characters representing text.

questions.question: What is the default value for an integer element in a Go array if not explicitly initialized?
How do you access the third element of an array named `myArray` in Go?
What is the key difference between a Go slice and a Go array?
options: Slices are always fixed-size, while arrays are dynamic.
Arrays can hold elements of different types, while slices can only hold one type.
Slices provide a dynamic view into an underlying array and can change size, while arrays have a fixed size.
There is no significant difference; they are interchangeable.

questions.question: A Go slice has two important properties: length and capacity. What do these represent?
options: Length is the number of elements currently in the slice; capacity is the maximum number of elements the underlying array can hold before reallocation.
Length is the maximum number of elements the underlying array can hold; capacity is the number of elements currently in the slice.
Length is the memory address of the first element; capacity is the memory address of the last element.
Length refers to the number of unique elements; capacity refers to the total number of elements.

questions.question: When you use the `append` function in Go to add an element to a slice, and the slice's current capacity is insufficient, what happens?
options: The program crashes with an out-of-bounds error.
The element is not added, and the slice remains unchanged.
A new, larger underlying array is allocated, elements are copied over, and the new element is added.
The existing underlying array is resized in-place, causing potential data corruption.

questions.question:
Consider the following Go code snippet:

```go
source := []int{1, 2, 3}
dest := make([]int, 2)
copy(dest, source)
```

What will be the value of `dest` after this operation?
When using the `range` keyword to iterate over a slice in Go, what does the second variable in `for index, value := range mySlice` represent?
options: The index of the current element.
The value of the current element.

questions.question: If you only need the values from a slice during iteration and not their indices, how should you structure your `range` loop in Go?
In Go, what is the primary purpose of the `if` statement?
options: To execute a block of code repeatedly a fixed number of times.
To execute a block of code only if a specific condition is true.
To choose one of many code blocks to execute based on a value.
To jump to a different part of the program.
